reviewText: The Cast:Kingdom Of Heaven (2005) is an epic action film directed by Ridley Scott (Gladiator) and stars Orlando Bloom (The Lord Of The Rings Trilogy) as Balian, Eva Green (Casino Royale) as Princess Sibylla, Jeremy Irons (The Man In The Iron Mask ) as  Tiberias the Marshal of Jerusalem, Edward Norton (American History X) as  King Baldwin IV, and Liam Neeson (Excalibur, Clash Of The Titans 2010) as Baron Godfrey of Ibalin, just to name a few of the most memorable.Brief Plot Summary:In the year of 1184, an illegitimate son of a Crusader Knight, named Balian, has just received a personal invitation, from his otherwise unknown father, to leave his hometown of  France and return to Jerusalem with him and his Crusader Knights. Reluctantly Balian agrees and begins to learn of his role as the new Baron of Ibalin. Seeking to receive forgiveness for his wife who had committed suicide and to redeem his faith in God, Balian arrives in Jerusalem to find it in a religious upheaval.A group of mercenary knights known as Crusaders defend Jerusalem  known as  "The Holy Land" from an Islamic people known as  the Saracens and  Saladin (Ghassan Massoud), leader of the Muslim forces, who claim to have been stripped of their right to the Holy Land over 100 years ago.. Now, with the majority of the Crusader Knights led by Guy de Lusignan (Marton Csokas) and Raynald of Chtillon (Brendan Gleeson), they raid and pillage under the guise of Christendom and provoke a war that could bring the peace treaty, kept in place by King Baldwin IV, to it's very knees.It will ultimately fall upon Balian to restore peace for not only the Christians and Jews but also for Muslims. If Balian is to accomplish this feat; he must turn against fanaticism caused by religion and resort to understanding the importance of free will and by making the right choices and preserving moral conciseness.Acting and Cinematography:The acting was very convincing by the entire cast and from the supporting actors involved. Most notable to me were Orlando Bloom who did not seem to remind me of his character from The Lord of the Rings and from Edward Norton who displayed much emotion despite being restricted of facial expressions by a steel mask that hid his entire face. The set locations were visually awing and become the focal point of making this film a three hour journey of pure "eye-candy". There are gorgeous landscapes and impressive costume designs that appear to be true/accurate to the time period.My Opinion Of The Film:I had seen the butchered version of this film when it first was released and was quite disappointed. This abridged version of the film left much to be desired. Epic battle sequences would consist of a large amount of build-up and then end just as quickly as they began. As an example; cuts were made in the middle of fight scenes and would end with a showing of the aftermath.  Huge gaps in character development made following the complicated story-lines difficult and combined with missing sections of the battle scenes only left much to be desired and not much to be remembered.When I first heard about a re-issue of this film in its entirety and as intended by director Ridley Scott, I became very excited and pessimistic of any real improvements. So often there are "Directors Cuts" that accomplish nothing more than adding deleted scenes and providing little depth to the plot or pacing of the film. I was very uncertain that this film would do any better. Proudly I can assure my readers that in the case of this film...that could be no further from the end result of Kingdom Of Heaven now shown in its entirety. Plot pacing and character development is improved ten-fold. Scenes that did not seem to make much sense can now easily be understood with great clarity.Let's face it; a movie that consists of so much plot detail and historical depth cannot be rushed through and be able to remain "epic". This film and its story are truly epic in scale and vision. I was immediately glued to my seat the entire time and was on more than several occasions uttering the word "wow".  I wanted to see more of the battle scenes that were previously cut out and boy does this version deliver!Characters that I did not really care about before suddenly become important and provided me the emotional attachment that I longed for. Anyone who has seen the theatrical release and found themselves undecided whether to like or dislike this film... owe it to themselves to fully be able to make that choice. In the words of Ridley Scott during the introduction of this version cannot be stated any better and further expands my POV here:"When you're flying into the third act; there are some elements in here that some people might argue as being, too long or take too long to get there, but I think you should see what it is and judge for yourself.." - Ridley Scott

reviewText: Director's Cut:First of all, let me say that the following review seeks to address many different aspects of this film, including the contents provided in the Director's Cut package.  Therefore, let me prime this by saying that the Director's Cut is far superior to the original Theatrical Version, and although I still have some reservations towards Kingdom of Heaven (KOH), if you are going to watch this film the Director's cut is the way to go.  Ridley has added some 45 minutes of unseen footage to the theatrical release for this version, and it not only adds to the film, but it makes it coherent.  As well as the additional footage, the documentaries and featurettes are worth watching if you are interested in the film or in the filmmaking process.Documentaries and Featurettes:While the documentaries and featurettes provide much insight into filmmaking, you will have to sit through an exposé of Ridley Scott's hubris just to access it.  For instance, Ridley and his cohorts spend excess time bragging about the sophistry of their non-theatrical release - even making claims that the average movie goer is too ignorant to understand the depth and complexity of Ridley's full vision.  But, when we examine the characters they are all fairly one dimensional, nor is the plot anything to brag about considering that the actual crusades were far more interesting.  Ridley also spends lots of time prancing around with his nose in the air spurting out the "f" word as if it were the most cultured word in the English language.  However, Ridley's attitude aside, the documentaries and featurettes do provide access behind the scenes of the film and into Ridley's creative vision, which if you are curious minded like me, provides ample educational and entertaining material.Historical Accuracy:Having watched the bonus material in the Director's cut version, I can say that the production team spends extensive time detailing the various processes employed in order to maintain historical accuracy.  Furthermore, three historians are interviewed in order to analyze some of the historical differences that non-the-less ended up in the film.  Throughout the historical analysis, the excuse is given that artistic license is required for a historical-fiction film; and therefore, the historical differences aren't worth nitpicking.  Furthermore, the historians and production team seem to agree that accurate historical epics would result in a documentary rather than a drama.  Unfortunately, this logic is not only ill informed, but is a contradiction from the marketing pitches used to promote this film.  One need only open the insert that comes with the Director's Cut to find an example of this marketing strategy:"To tell the story as accurately as possible, screenwriter Monahan worked from primary sources, referring to the firsthand accounts (in translation) of people who were present while history was being made rather than interpretations written by others through the subsequent centuries."Which begs the question why then allow Ridley Scott's subsequent interpretation of the historical events?It's not that this film required historical accuracy, but when you market it as such it should maintain the accuracy implied.  If you are interested in learning more about this, Wikipedia has a pretty decent rundown of the inaccuracies.Christianity vs. Islam:It's pretty obvious to the careful viewer that Ridley Scott had an axe to grind with Christianity, and in particular Catholicism.  Ridley not only dumbs down the crusader's faith, he portrays it as ignorant, absurd, brutish, vacuous, and trite.  Ridley's biased attitude seeps through numerous characters including the Knights Templar who use the token phrase "God Will's It!" as an excuse to do anything they like, Priests who steal, cheat, and lie, Monks who claim that goodness is fighting for those who can't defend themselves (a very shallow view of Catholic morality), an Atheist centrist (i.e. Balian played by Orlando Bloom) who sleeps around with a married woman yet still claims purity and uprightness, and a Bishop who exclaims near the end of the film "convert to Islam and convert back later!" - leading me to believe that Ridley has never dared to examine the lives of the thousands of martyrs in the Catholic faith who all chose death rather than conversion.  These characterizations only exist in Hollywood's delusional world as the real Crusaders gave up money, land, and family in order to defend Eastern Christendom from Muslim invasion and occupation, and in order to purify themselves through holy pilgrimage.  In fact, piety and Christian devotion had to exist to a greater degree than recognized in order to motivate the expense, hardship, and renunciation of material items and familial relationships that was required for Crusading.  Not to say that all Crusaders were pious and holy, they weren't, but most were, and they definitely had a reverence for Christ and their Catholic faith that doesn't exist in the mundane version of the Crusades shown here.As well as showing Catholicism as a religion composed of barbaric zealots, Catholic practice is almost wholly omitted in KOH.  For example, Ridley excludes Catholic Sacraments and prayer entirely from the film except for two short scenes involving last rites or the Anointing of the Sick, which he then uses as an opportunity to attack the Sacrament of Confession - Godfrey (Liam Neeson) sluffs off confession with the claim that he doesn't regret the adulterous act that produced Balian, and King Baldwin (Edward Norton) dismisses confession altogether by exclaiming that "I will confess to God when I see Him."  With this much anti-Catholic bias one should wonder why Catholics weren't more upset when this film was released.  It's almost as if Ridley feels it is his obligation to slap Catholics in the face, and he is only adding fuel to the anti-Catholic fire that was ignited by Hollywood long ago.Conversely, when it comes to the Islamic religion an extreme amount of respect and reverence are offered by Ridley and his team.  The Islamic forces are largely depicted as civilized, deep, philosophic, and tolerant people, who are simply trying to fend off war mongering Christians.  Many assumptions are made regarding the Islamic side of the issue; for example, it is just a given that the Holy Land was Muslim occupied long before Christians had stolen it.  Furthermore, Ridley gives Muslim prayer plenty of face time in the film, and even shoots the Christians jealously looking on - for of course, this degree of spirituality is far beyond anything a mere Christian could ever understand, let alone obtain.Furthermore, the additional documentary footage reveals much about Ridley's view of the Islamic religion.  For instance, he remarks during one interview that he wants to portray religion with as much respect and reverence as possible, and he clarifies, "especially the Islamic religion."  In reality, the actual Islamic militants were much more raw and brutal than Ridley has depicted, and the whole tolerance theme he applies to Saladin/Islam is a load of rubbish - largely invented by 19th century historians who were trying to redefine the Crusades in the face of existing conflicts.Set and Costume Design:Besides the fact that the Jerusalem set excludes the hill that Jerusalem sits upon, the set and costume designs are magnificent.  Actually, the grandiose scale of the sets and costumes really makes the film worth watching.  If anything, one can get a good idea of the feel of medieval times just from the costumes and sets.  The flags are also worth looking into as Ridley's team spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on flags alone and had hundreds of different types, which are all authentically recreated!  It's worth the time to watch the Featurettes with Janty Yates, as she provides insight into the huge effort involved in creating the numerous costumes for this epic.  Furthermore, the weapon design team did a fabulous job, one step below Lord of the Rings but awesome non-the-less.Special Effects:Again, compared to Lord of the Rings, Kingdom of Heaven is a notch below, but for technical battle scenes and vast armies it is still utterly impressive.  I would certainly recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys great action sequences, as KOH offers plenty of eye candy.Score:The score, written and conducted by Harry Gregson-Williams, is both fitting and enchanting.  With undercurrents from other Middle Eastern epics, Williams uses vocal performances and orchestral sounds to woo the audience into the movie.  The music certainly outweighed the theatrical release, but with the Director's cut it seems to blend well.Budget and Theatrical Release:For a big time epic Hollywood production, Kingdom of Heaven performed poorly to say the least.  It is probably one of the bigger flops in Hollywood history, especially considering that Ridley Scott is one of the most highly acclaimed action directors of our times.  However, having watched the Theatrical version, its easy to see why it failed - the movie was one dimensional and the plot was incoherent.  There is a 30 minute presentation by Ridley and team in the Director's Cut package that dialogues the numerous failings of the theatrical release, and it is well worth watching as the team offers invaluable insight into the disappointment and propriety involved in marketing and cutting Hollywood movies.  In short, Ridley Scott makes the claim that his original version of the movie (i.e. with the boy) is wholly preferable to the rubbish he ended up cutting.  However, under pressure from the studio, Ridley collaborated with the effort to shorten the film and remove the boy from the movie.Perhaps, as Ridley claims, the theatrical release would have been more successful had his version been shown rather than the watered down release that ended up in cinemas.  We'll never know what the outcome would have been.  However, if I had to speculate, I would say that even though the Director's cut is vastly superior to its theatrical predecessor, American audiences would still have avoided the film because of its clear and arduous attacks on Christianity.  As indicated by another viscously anti-Christian movie, the Da Vinci Code - it shattered box offices around the world, but took in pitiful amounts in the U.S for a production of its size.Oh well, better luck next time Ridley!
summary: Ridley's Epic Still Doesn't Make The Cut
Title: N/A

reviewText: Enough, already! I'm tired, dog-tired, of the hackneyed, predictable and perturbing portrait of Christianity in general--and of Catholicism in particular--that movies like Kingdom of Heaven (or, take King Arthur as another disturbing example) foist upon the (presumably) ignorant masses.In this film, virtually every historical Christian, i.e., Catholic, is cast as blasphemous, fanatical or, when showing any positive qualities at all, as decidedly anti-Catholic(!) in their sentiment--as those who merely endure their membership in the Church for simple lack of anything better to do at the time, but who actually march to the tune of their own, self-styled and flippantly proclaimed creeds. The crusaders, conspicuously bearing the Cross, are shown to be nothing more than lusty, greedy, bloodthirsty opportunists. The ecclesiastics (priest and bishop alike) are caricatured as self-absorbed, thieving, sniveling, cowardly buffoons. On the other hand, Muslims, given more popular press, are depicted as a people with an obviously higher and better strain of spirituality than those "dirty, rotten" Christians.But the real hero is the ever "Enlightened Pagan" or, at best, the supremely "Syncretistic Pelagian," who shows us that "real" men don't really need the useless trappings of the Church--or religion, for that matter--in order to become "real, good" men. The true hero is the man who, answering to himself and no one else--including God, forges his own faith; the man who promotes religious tolerance to the point of acknowledging no religion at all, and ultimately of having no religion himself. For it is then, and only then, that the world--rid especially of those problematic Christians--will be a far, far better place for you and for me and for everyone else.In short, a sickeningly revisionist rewrite of the crusades, motivated by a deliberate and rapidly tiresome anti-Catholic agenda. The idea advanced in the film that crusading supposedly absolved one's sins is absurd. Or how about "Christian Jihad" in the cry from the crazy-faced priest welcoming the crusaders into the Holy Land: "Killing an infidel isn't murder! It's the gateway to heaven!"? Or the shot of the knight allegedly praying the Rosary two or three centuries before this devotion gained a foothold in popular piety? Those who will so desperately to rid their present day world of Christianity, but who desperately fail, then revert to trying to rid the historical world of Christianity. In the latter attempt, Kingdom of Heaven (along with The Da Vinci Code, King Arthur and others of its ilk) fails desperately--again.If you want to know what really happened, turn off your TV, get a good history book of the Crusades and read it. If you prefer a fictionalized fantasy/action adventure, whereby you may absent yourself from using your mind while abandoning yourself wholesale to the propaganda of Hollywood film-makers, watch Kingdom of Heaven. Your willful ignorance is their obscene bliss.

reviewText: Ok,I'm gonna list the things about the movie that I liked.-Acting was fantastic(especially Bloom,who seems an entirely different actor than the one in "Pirates").-Period accuracy(in warfare,dialogue,and overall actions).-The score was compelling and totally fitting for the mood(Harry-Greggson Williams from Narnia was the composer).-Moral obligation(Bloom's character is driven by an honest desire to do right.This rather sets him apart from many other characters of like movie genre who are driven by honour,glory,and basically to defend the innocent,which isn't bad.It's just a different perspective than his).-Great battle sequences(Although there is violence to spare,the viewer is often spared the vision of beheadings,goring,and carnage in great detail,although there is quite a bit of blood.But I found that the viewer is often given adequate warning for other disturbing images.The battles themselves are brilliant with stunning choreography and a general understanding of war tactics.The besieging of Jerusalem is not unlike the storming of Minas Tirith in the Lord of the Rings).-The love story(Bloom's character refrains from taking the woman he loves as his own because she is married and a queen.There is only one brief scene of "love" between them which is good.Her husband dies and he gets her anyways so it all works out).-The growth of the main character(he goes from a grieving blacksmith to a student of a great warrior to a leader of a town to the commander of the army.His personal developement is gripping,too).The things that I didn't like were early in the movie and soon dealt with(rapid progression and unrealistic circumstances),so I enjoyed the movie quite well.Entertaining and enlightening,this movie is a really good one.It is a bit long and may take patience to finish it,but it is worth watching.Sorry if I ruined the story for you.

reviewText: I have always been an enthusiast of Ridley Scott's movie.  Every frames are picture perfect and Ridley himself even remarked jokingly that he's been categorised as a visualist (looks good but no substance).  Despite that this movie is better viewed in the cinema, the second dic with the extra features are exemplary in this instance.  There are two substantial documentaries that allow the viewers to understand deeper about the Crusades, comparing the facts against the fiction, getting a glimpse of the thoughts and reflections of the actors and actresses, planning process, production process and so forth.  In many other DVD compilation, we would have behind the scene extra which is more like a promotional material but not here, where all documentaries have gotten substance to them.  The movie is very relevant in today's situation where Muslims are still proclaiming jihad towards the infidels and Christians (in the form of USA with its supporters) invade and occupy Iraq and now, talking about exerting its muscle power towards Syria and Iran.  Then, there's the problem spot itself, Jerusalem where Muslims are still fending themselves or exerting themselves against the might of the Jews and the Christians.  The movie's intent is obvious.  It's actually an anti-war movie that believes in forward thinking leadership and resolving conflict towards dialogues and working together as shown by King Baldwin and Salahuddin.  Can you imagine President Bush and Osama coming face to face and working through an uneasy alliance?  This movie is different from The Gladiators because the focus is never on Maximus but about Jerusalem itself.  Characters that are featured in the movie form the total sum of the movie.  The whole time sitting through the movie, it never comes to me that it's about Balian but about conflicting and amiable personalities that either work against or for one another.  Don't take my word for it but this movie is a grand epic and very well-executed.  God is in details and from little subtle hints given in the picture shots, we get to understand the society, the philosophy, the costume, the diet, the geography  , the architecture, the warefare and its weaponary of its time.  The gesture of Salahuddin picking up a fallen cross and putting it right on the table mindfully is a very potent symbol of his respect and tolerance of other religion.  The movie brings forth a point that some people use religion for the greater good and some people hide behind the facade or religion to garner power and influence.  Once they are corrupted by power, they are incorrigible and would start committing evil.  It's quite remarkable that one of the Ten Commandments is Thou Shall Not Kill and yet, people can't still abide by TEN simple Commandments.  A memorable movie that anyone should have in their collections.  Highly recommended.  I'm really saddened by the fact that it didn't do well in the box-office.  Perhaps, it's due to people's denial of the inherent message in the movie, a movie that shows a more humane side of the Muslims, where the American market can't and won't accept right now especially when their sons and daughters are fighting a war that doesn't belong to them.

reviewText: Come on now, if you've already seen the film and love it, it isn't fair to read reviews and vote "not helpful," because you weren't going to buy the DVD anyway; you already have it.That said, it was hard to choke down this line from the editorial review:  "It's hard to believe Ridley Scott's handsome epic won't become the cinematic touchstone of the Crusades for years to come. "Actually, it is easy to believe.  The film is not an accurate depiction of anything associated with the Crusades.  Ridley Scott coughs up the same visually spectacular but morally ambiguous and substance-free film he is notorious for.As for inaccuracies, the weapons, armor and combat styles are inaccurate.  The theology presented is inaccurate for both sides.  The ethnicity is inaccurate.The dialogue is so 21st century it is almost painful to listen to the anachronisms and malapropisms. The political correctness may go down well in Hollywood these days but it is hardly faithful to the times of the film and it is almost surreal to imagine any European man of the eleventh or twelfth century behaving the way they are portrayed herein!But hey, if you just want to see an "epic" and don't care about veracity, if mediocre acting is all that you require, or if you are keen on Orlando Bloom, go for it!

reviewText: I remember not really liking the abbreviated (two-hour?) version that came out in the theater. Probably because the characters and plot weren't really properly developed in the short version.I've got a personal interest in the history of the Middle East and Jerusalem.Although Scott takes substantial liberties with the history of the Baldwin dynasty / Queen Sybilla / Saladin et al. he still does a bang-up visual / cinematographic job of recreating a 12th century Jerusalem and outlining the intrigue between the King, the Knights Templar, the church, and the enemies (internal and external) of the Crusaders. Scott also nails the grand themes of the Crusades -- religious motivation vs. economic / political motivation to capture and hold Jerusalem, etc.This DVD should be on anyone's shelf with the Lawrence of Arabia director's cut DVD.

reviewText: Kingdom of Heaven is the story of a French ironworker in early 12th century Europe who heads to the Levant to find redemption. What he finds when he arrives is nothing that he expected (or could expect) and the movie is the story of the personal and social challenges of the era. It certainly has a number of messages it attempts to make--both overt and sublime--and we may find that we don't agree with everything the movie has to say. But its almost impossible not to be impressed and intrigued with what we see in the story. It's a story that makes us think, and it's also a story that helps us learn a critical piece of history. It's a story that entertains. It's a grand work made accessible to nearly anyone. And it's a story that will likely leave you wishing to learn more.Kingdom of Heaven is a panoramic epic, eminently suited to the enlarged vistas of the super wide screen. It shows its best with huge, wide landscapes of cities, troops, and landscapes, and proceeds to fill them with color, detail, and power. It is a lushly filmed piece that finds its best home in the Blu-Ray format, which alone to date is able to present in the home setting the original intent of the film's look. It is gorgeous to view, with so much detail and visual activity in each scene that it will take multiple viewings to take it all in. There are few films that are as visually beautiful as this one.Further contributing to the experience, the Blu-Ray edition of the movie comes with lossless, 5.1 audio. This means that, if you have a home studio system, you will experience a superior audio presentation, but even two channel (stereo) systems will provide a much more clear and powerful soundtrack. This is a good thing, because the musical composition of the piece is hauntingly beautiful. It's a multimedia experience when coupled with the high definition video of Blu-Ray.Of course, directing and acting in the movie is first rate. There is little to be desired in the execution of the film, although some will say that the director's cut in the Blu-Ray format, at over three hours, is way too long. It's a valid point, and it's the same one that was made against The Good, the Bad, and the Ugly. But in both these cases, the director and the story have a lot to say, and I would venture to bet that few will regret the time spent (on either work). Here, the story is much more complicated than GBU, and it can also be said that a little knowledge of history would be helpful to understand the story. But every possible support is built into the film so that anyone can follow.An amazing work on virtually any measure, learn some history while enjoying the story.
summary: An Epic Story of Medieval Times

reviewText: Filmed in the picturesque lands of Spain and Morocco, this is a film about the epic battles for control of the holyland between the Christians and Muslims.  Saladin, legendary muslim commander and field marshal seeks to displace the Christians from  Jerusalem, but has made  peace with the Christian king.Balian, a french blacksmith (Orlando Bloom) travels with his father, Godfrey (Liam Neeson) to try to erase his sins in this world. He is befriended by the king and then battles with members of the Knights Templar who would make war upon Saladin.  He becomes involved with the kings sister, the beautiful Sybilla (Natalie Cox) and ultimately takes command of the Christian forces there after the king perishes from leprosy, and the new king and Templar leader is captured.Balian successfully defends Jerusalem, but then surrenders it to save the people.  Sybilla and Balian return to France to start a new life.  Balian's directions to the Holy Land are: "Go  to where men speak Italian, then go on to where thay speak something else."Though the story is a fiction, the events did, in fact, happen.  Saladin did displace the Christians from the Holy Land and King Richard the Lionheart tried to get it back.Bloom is excellent in the role of Balian, though not the womanizer he was in the movie, Troy.  I really love this film.  The picture quality in the CD was very good, however, the sound seemed somewhat difficult.  Perhaps it was the way the actors speak.  The movie is long at 144 minutes, but there is so much action, you never seem to get bored or lose focus.I would recommend this movie to anyone who likes biblical history or action adventure.  It is a first class production.
summary: GO  TO WHERE MEN SPEAK ITALIAN AND THEN ON TO WHERE THEY SPEAK SOMETHING ELSE

reviewText: I WATCHED THIS DVD FOR MORE THAN AN HOUR.  THE SETTINGS WERE AMAZING AND THE CLARITY WAS ABOVE REPROACH. HOWEVER, THE BACKGROUND MUSIC WAS SO OVERWHELMING THAT I HAD TO REDUCE MY VOLUME ON A STATE OF THE ART HEADSET.THE HORSES APPEARED TO RUN OFF THE SCREEN AND INTO MY LIVING ROOM.ALAS, I ONLY HAD A VAGUE IDEA OF WHAT IT WAS ALL ABOUT. TRUE THE SOUND QUALITY WAS ALL THAT WAS PROMISED, THE DIALGOE WAS IFFY.  AT TIMES I WOULD GET A VAGUE IDEA WHAT WAS SAID AND OTHER TIMES I JUST SAT THERE LIKE A DUMMY WITH NO IDEA WHAT WAS BEING SAID. AT THAT TIME I CALLED IT A NIGHT AND CHECKED THE PACKAGE AND NOTED THAT IT CONTAINED SUB TITLES, WHICH I WAS UNAWARE OF WHEN I STARTED PLAING THE DVD.I HAVE NOTICED LATELY THAT THERE ARE OTHER DVD'S, BOTH BLU RAY AND OTHERS THAT ALSO SUFFER FROM THE POOR QUALLITY SOUND OF THE SPOKEN DIALOGUE.INFORMATIVELY, I HAVE THE ENTIRE SET OF THE DIANA RIGG/JOHN STEED AVENGERS THAT RAN FROM 1965-1967. WHEN I PLAY THESE DVD'S THE SOUND QUALIITY OF THE SPOKEN WORD IS AS CLEAR AS CRYSTAL AND IN MY OPINION THE OVERALL SOUND QUALLITY OF THIS COLLECTION IS FAR SUPERIIOR OR WOULD MATCH THE BEST OF HIGH DEFINITION DVD'S.LASTLY, I WOULD HUMBLY RECOMMEND THAT THE FOCUS SHOULD BE ON THE SPOKEN DIALOGUE AND SOFTEN THE OVERWHEMING AND OVERPOWERING BACKGROUND MUSIC.THE ONLY ALTERNATIVE I HAVE AT HAND IS TO CHOOSE THE SUB TITLES FEATURE WHICH SADLY IS NOT AVAILABLE ON OTHER DVD'S THAT REALLY WOULD PROFIT BY IT.HOWEVER, TO THOSE WHO ARE FORTUNATE TO HAVE HEARING THAT MATCHES DOGS ORBARN OWLS THEN THIS DVD IS FOR YOU.ROBERT LYONSRENO, NEVADA

reviewText: Ridley Scott's majestic, provocative KINGDOM OF HEAVEN (Fox), never achieved mainstream status. Perhaps it was the contemporary "crusader" implications of the U.S. invasion of Iraq or the strong support of Israel by American evangelicals and the rise of radical Islamic terrorists that chilled the public's desire to see a film that explores and exploits the core conflicts between Christianity and Islam regarding Jerusalem.Criticized by both Arabs and Christians as taking the other's side, the film's an epic adventure that follows Balian (Orlando Bloom), a simple French blacksmith who discovers he's a nobleman and assumes his father's place in Richard the Lionheart's Third Crusade (1187-1192) to reclaim Jerusalem from a Saladin.  The main characters are based on real people with the exception of Balian's father.This convincing visual recreation of another era catches arguments for both sides and spotlights the self-serving agendas of those who influence the powers-that-be.The details of siege warfare in the climactic battle for Jerusalem, the huge scale of the confrontation and the fiery catapults are a wonder of modern filmmaking.Everyone I know who has actually seen this impressive film has enjoyed it.For more on this relevant theme, read James Reston's terrific book "Warrior's of God" and see the superb two-hour PBS documentary "Holy Warriors" now on DVD (Paramount).

reviewText: In addition to its wide-ranging battle scenes and handsome production values, Ridley Scott's Medieval epic "Kingdom of Heaven" boasts a greater complexity of character and depth of theme than we are accustomed to finding in a film of this type.  Although set in the late 12th Century, the film has a great deal of relevance to the world of today, seeing as how the Christian West and the Muslim East are once again at each others' throats much as they were back then.  Only the names and the weaponry seem to have changed.  With an eye towards fairness, perhaps, the movie makes it very clear that there are men of war and men of peace on both sides of the conflict, although, if the truth be told, the Christians come out slightly less noble than their Islamic counterparts in the film.By the time the story begins, the Crusades have been waging on and off for nearly a hundred years already.  And although a fragile peace seems to have taken a temporary hold in the Christian-ruled city of Jerusalem, forces from both without and within are threatening to rend the tender garment holding that peace together.  Orlando Bloom plays the young blacksmith, Balian, son of the beloved Sir Godfrey (Liam Nissan), who is hoping to find his redemption for killing a priest by becoming a knight and dedicating his life to defending that holiest of cities to the best of his abilities.Beyond its rather excessive running time, the biggest weakness in the film is Bloom himself who makes for a very bland, very pallid central figure, one whose "romance" with Sibylla, the queen of Jerusalem, is the least interesting aspect of the film.  However, there are fine compensatory supporting performances by Liam Nissan, Jeremy Irons and Ghassan Massoud as the great Islamic leader, Saladin, who, like Balian, is portrayed as almost a reluctant warrior in this titanic struggle for religious domination.And indeed, it is the sociopolitical parallels that the film draws between its own time and ours that ultimately lifts "Kingdom of Heaven" a rung or two above the ordinary.

reviewText: I am a student of history and have read extensively in this period so I was looking forward to this film.  Unfortunately this is a terribly flawed film and this begins with Orlando Bloom who is terribly miscast. Dirt and grit does not make you either masculine or heroic.  Bloom is alleged to be a "blacksmith" but he is probably about 50 pounds too light to be convincing in that role.  We are expected to believe that in a matter of hours / days he becomes a skilled warrior capable of ending off some well armed and mounted men-at-arms.  Mastering the broadsword requires a great deal more practice.The villains in the film are based on actual characters and come across pretty much like I think they were.  The Muslims are portrayed in a rather sympathetic light which isn't too far from the historical record.  I thought the film was relatively slow, Bloom was miscast, but the photography was good as were the costumes.  I thought the storyline was a little too politically correct and the ending was simply not believable.  A little more action might have helped.  Overall a so-so film but one that could have been better.

reviewText: This is a great film that will age well. In one respect it soars above most military and historical epics. It does a better job than any film I know of in getting at the philosophy behind what the military calls "the warrior ethos."  It illustrates that philosophy and psychology better than any of the U.S. military services' assorted creeds, codes and oaths. Historically the Just War Tradition has always centered on protection of the weak and unarmed, those unable to defend themselves. Scott elevates the ideas of selflessness and defense of the innocent to the controlling ideas of the film. A maturing sense of honor is the driving force behind development of the main character Balian (the Army should pay to use this epic as a training film).In the film Saladin is a reluctant cynic who has morally resigned himself to the dirtiness of his business while doing his best to avoid war. His counterpart among the Jerusalem Christians is the character Tiberias, the king's military commander, portrayed well by Jeremy Irons. The uneasy peace held tenuously together by Saladin, King Baldwin, and Tiberias keeps the ideological dogs of war at bay.When everything they've struggled to maintain falls apart, one pure knight (Bloom as Balian) is able to salvage some order from the chaos. I disagree with those who think he is miscast. His laconic humility fits the script well. When Saladin decides to besiege Jerusalem, Balian's speech to the forces defending the city ranks with Shakespeare's Saint Crispin's Day "band of brothers" speech put into Henry V's mouth at Agincourt. In my opinion Balian's words are better, certainly more profound if not more poetic, and the humbleness of his character is key to his message.Other aspects of the film that ring true are Balian's and Saladin's respect for their own dead and regret over the losses of war. The despicable manipulative influence and interference by churchmen in the film also strikes an important chord: priestcraft emerges as the root of all evil. One cannot escape the images of superstition in the film and how they variously work to undo reason and order. Balian rises to the occasion in the image of a world-weary savior, one whose moral compass has escaped the trammels of religious prejudice.The film is loaded with fine acting. From my perspective, Ridley Scott just gets better with age.

reviewText: I really enjoyed the theatrical cut, and now, get ready for all the nice storylines that were deleted.  What you'll see on the director's cut (referenced from AICN) SPOILERS AHEAD!!:- did you realize that the priest at the beginning is actually the half-brother of Balian (Orlando Bloom)? Their relationship is much more complicated and unpleasant in this version, and we learn that Balian is in jail following his wife's death, thanks to his brother's claim that he is possessed by the devil.- We also learn that Balian was an engineer before he became a blacksmith, that he built war machines when he was part of an army, and he's released from prison because the local lord needs Balian's help. So much more work is put into the establishment of Balian's character that by the time we actually meet him in the film now, we have a sense of who he is.- The lord that Balian works for? Turns out, he's Neeson's brother, and when Godfrey shows up in the village, he's coming home. There's an entire scene that takes place at the castle where it's clear that his absence made it possible for his brother to take over, something that his brother doesn't want to see change. Since Godfrey has no heir, if he dies, then his new lands also become the property of the brother, something that makes more sense of the battle scenes involving Neeson and his group of soldiers.- When Neeson goes to talk to Balian the first time, he stops at the door to the smith's shop, looking out at a particular spot. He flashes back to when he was younger, to when he was with Balian's mother, and that one moment says all we need to know about the particular paradise that Godfrey seeks and that he knows he'll never find again. It explains so much about why he would want to come and make amends and reach out to Balian. He's looking for absolution, and he figures he can find it this way, and the film shows us instead of just telling us.- Baldwin IV is shown refusing the last sacrament from Patriarch Heraclius.- Another major change is the re-insertion of the character of Baldwin V (who was shown in some of the trailers), here depicted as the son of Sibylla by Guy. He is portrayed as suffering from leprosy, like his uncle. His death is depicted as an act of euthanasia by his mother, using poison.- Balian also fights a climactic duel with Guy.- Additionally, Eva Green's role as the Queen has been expanded, and she's not there just for Orland Bloom's sexual interest.- More insight into absolution, forgiveness, and politics in this time period.
summary: Too bad it didn't do better at the box office

reviewText: It's definitely eye candy, with spectacular scenes of massed armies and trebuchets hurling fireballs. Unfortunately, it's also "jolt" filmmaking at its worst. As in Gladiator, everything is pumped up to the same level of intensity, through the use of quick camera cuts, exaggerated sound effects (I'm really getting to hate that "whoosh" that accompanies every sword swing in movies), reverb added to every bit of dialog to make the actors sound more convincing, plenty of gore, and constant music with lots of deep rumbling. When you take all this away, you have two or three decent performances, some lovely costumes, and a reasonably accurate sketch of the events leading up to the Third Crusade.As for the leading characters, the actors are not given much to work with: our hero mostly just struts around being handsome and knowledgeable, while Queen Sibylla, looking very goth, stares glumly wide-eyed at everything around her. The only character who really engages us, other than Bailin's father (Liam Neeson), is Saladin (Ghassan Massoud), bristling with strength and authority.I can't say I hated this movie as much as Gladiator. It's at least more coherent, and some attempt is made to let us know just what's going on in the battle scenes. Nonetheless it is far too reliant on cheap effects, and pays far too little attention to characterization, to be a great film.

reviewText: `Kingdom of Heaven' is an epic tale set during the Crusades and whilst this is rife with historical inaccuracies, it is also a fairly decent story of one man finding some peace and meaning in his life. Bloom plays the main character (Balian) and he manages to play the role reasonably well, although he doesn't seem to have enough grit at times. He puts on a brave show with his sword fights and gives the occasional rabble rousing speech now and again, but he is no William Wallace crying for `Freedom' although you get the feeling this was the image Scott was going for. This is based around the death of a king, his succession and the fall of Jerusalem and this could have lead to deep courtly intrigue and Machiavellian schemes to enhance the plot and though these elements are represented in the film, they are rather flat and without suspense. I think this stems from the fact that this is overlong (don`t be fooled by the time guide on Amazon), I have bought the directors cut of this and boy does it feel overlong by the end. This doesn't seem to have much pace, but plods on and on, when in reality it could be a snappy story full of chivalry, battles and honour. For all that, this is still a perfectly enjoyable film and once you settle into it's rhythm you can truly appreciate it for it's epic scope.Feel free to check out my blog which can be found on my profile page.

reviewText: The director's cut edition of Kingdom of Heaven gives this film its justice it so rightly deserved when it first came on the big screen.  Knowing little, but some of the crusades, this film is not only for entertainment, but used as education.  Not only did we learn about these true-life characters that shared our world around a thousand years ago, but we learned about humanity and frame of thought way back when.  Granted, this movie is not a completely accurate factual representation of characters and events, but it is factual in the sense that it tells us how we lived, how we loved, and what we believed in.  When I first saw Gladiator, I was amazed by the cinematography, design and costumes of the time.  Enriching characters that sucked you into the film.  A sign of a great movie is when you no longer think of Russell Crowe or Joaquin Phoenix as playing Maximus and Commodus respectfully, but when you think you are actually watching a Roman gladiator and actually watching a Roman Emperor duel it out for control of Rome.  These great depictions of these type of characters is what Ridley Scott brings to Kingdom of Heaven.  What was even better about the acting this time around is that not all the characters in this movie are as overhyped and well-known for that matter.  Case and point, King Baldwin IV.  I truly understood this man and his message and his role back in Jerusalem and took him for a king, nothing more.  Later I came to find out that the character of Baldwin was played by Ed Norton.  All these other images and thoughts of Norton in his other roles came into my head.  Never would I think he'd be capable of such a role.  But that's the magic of it all.  I don't want to go into great detail on all the characters, but it's the smaller characters of this movie that really sell this film as a great film.  Yes, the storyline had its flaws and there were some gaps, but just as in Troy and Gladiator, the acting of other characters and smaller roles makes the movie.  Were we not inspired by the great late Oliver Reed as Proximo??David Thewlis as the Hospitaller.  His claim to fame is his great acting in the Harry Potter films, yet these small scenes in which he was in, really make the viewer understand the film's message, his character's message.  The line "What god desires is here (points to Balian's head) and here (points to Balian's heart).  And what you decide to do every day will make you a good man...or not." is powerful.  In a turbulent world of politics, religion, and greed, his character stands out in the film as having his morals and faith before going to battle, for "God".  And finally, Martin Csokas as Guy de Lusignan.  Is this not the greatest medieval villain you have ever seen?  Whether you hated his character as the leader of the Templars (which he really wasn't), you sort of wanted him to appear more and more throughout the movie.  He's the antagonist, the opposite to Balian, yet his character is powerful, royal, and evil.  "You sit at my table"  "Is it not the king's table?"  "Is it now?  I have not seen the king at it for quite some time.  In France, this would not inherit."  While the writing was weak in some parts, mainly the ending of the film, the dialogue between the characters was superbly fitting for the time.
summary: ...a kingdom of consciene, a Kingdom of Heaven.

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of historical dramas, especially when the filmmaker has the vision and budget to really capture the look, feel and spectacle of past events.  When it was announced that Ridley Scott was going to make a film about the Crusades, I was really excited about the possibilities... this director knows how to manage big budgets, big sets and action scenes involving casts of thousands and get it onto the screen. Scott is a superb technical film maker and an intelligent guy.Nonetheless, Kingdom of Heaven suffers too much from the Hollywood treatment and I'm not talking about the casting choices as some reviewers were quick to criticize.Orlando Bloom, as Balian of Ibelin, is just fine in the lead role, as are the majority of others cast in the film. The Muslim actor who portrays Saladin gives a particularly noteworthy and fairly accurate account of this historical figure.  Nope, the fault is with Bill Monahan's script (and Scott sticking to it, so faithfully)  Instead of showing Balian in a reasonably accurate manner as the wealthy inheritor of an estate in the Holy land, he's depicted as a troubled blacksmith- one who's wife has just committed suicide and who's brother is a psychotic and manipulative priest. In a long, convoluted series of scenes, Balian kills his brother, is reconnected with his long lost father who is shortly mortally wounded. He takes up the Cross (reluctantly) and arrives in Messina, ready to travel to the Holy Lands and mange his fathers estate.... but not before he's been shipwrecked !It takes nearly a hour of this convoluted fiction to set the stage for the religious, political and military conflicts that are to come.  Monahan finally settles down and produces some moments of clarity when Balian arrives in the Holy Land.  Of course, any historian of the Crusades could find fault in nearly ever scene, but who in the general audience would notice or care.  We should expect that in a Hollywood extravaganza, a romantic interest would be created, where none actually existed -and that's OK, too!Screen writer Monahan, however, is not content with simply fleshing out and elaborating on the fascinating characters of Baldwin the Leper King, his sister Sibylla, her eventual husband King Guy d' Lusignan and the rogue robber baron Reynald d'Chatillon - he fashions them into over-the-top cartoons.  There's nothing at all subtle or nuanced about the way these characters are depicted. Guy has all the emotional depth of Snidely Whiplash, while Balian plays his adversary as the slightly morose Dudley Do-Right.  Reynald is reduced to a psychopathic killer, rather than a shrewd, albeit violent, political operator. The leper king is gentle, wise and always diplomatic, to the point where it seems he's been sedated throughout Monahan's script.Of course, when it comes to the broader military conflict, Ridley Scott is in his directorial element and the movie captures plenty of thrilling battles, inglorious defeats and individual heroics, while keeping fairly true to the historical record. This is where Kingdom of Heaven borders on being a cinematic classic and there are awesome spectacles of Jerusalem under siege.  Certainly, Ridley Scott and Monahan had the right idea - post 9/11 - to speak to the divisive nature that religion sparks in humanity and to question how theology, greed and power can corrupt peaceful cooperation.  This movie could have been better received and gotten its core message across to a broader audience, had it been more careful to avoid the obvious cliche's of the genre.  I don't even know where to begin discussing in how lousy the script concludes.Hey, the boxed set does contain a nifty full length documentary about the making of Kingdom of Heaven which is really enjoyable for fans of cinema - showing how tens of millions of dollars are spent to bring an epic to the screen, department by department.  That was a fun bonus.  It's a shame all those millions weren't spent crafting a film based on more accurate, and thus meaningful, script.
summary: Man, I really wanted to like this movie more than I did

reviewText: As I've done for the other Blu-Ray discs I own, I'm going to skip writing a review of the movie myself and instead focus on the Blu-Ray disc and quality it brings to the table.As far as the movie goes, I really enjoyed it. A well told story, great acting and scenery to die for, even on the DVD version.It should be noted for those that are fans of one codec over another, this disc was done using MPEG-2 compression. The majority of the Blu-Ray discs I own are actually. This is easily the best authored of all the MPEG-2 discs I own.The video quality is jaw dropping gorgeous. The HD content authored properly affords a level of clarity rivaled by nothing out there (probably goes for HD-DVD as well, though KoH isn't on HD-DVD). Fox has given us something that we can drop into the player and show off to friends and let them see the real difference between HD and SD. There are instances of film grain in things such as the sky, but this is minimal and given it's film origins, is acceptable for me at least. The only movies that shouldn't suffer this problem would be movies filmed/recorded on a digital medium. Colors are vibrant and gorgeous. Being able to see details on a horse that is running up from the far off distance when the same scene on DVD you can basically tell the horse's color and larger details, really makes the difference between HD and SD apparent.The audio on this disc is nothing short of amazing. It's mastered in DTS-MA. I don't currently own a receiver that can decode this stream internally so my setup is converting to LPCM. It still sounds amazing and the level of clarity is miles above DTS from DVD.Over all, while this particular Blu Ray disc is more expensive than similar releases from other studios, the authoring of the disc is of the highest quality. If you're looking for a good story and also something to show off the power of your HD setup, you can't go wrong with KoH.

reviewText: I am a history teacher and though I was aware historians were crying foul of the inaccuracies (and I noticed a good amount in the film) but despite these, I was very pleased with it.  I have to say that I tremendously admire Ridley Scott and the cast for making this film in these turbulent times.  His point was to show (primarily the Western world) a little piece about the clashes between Islam and Christianity.  And, be warned, this could cause tremendous animosity on all 3 sides: Christianity, Judaism, and Islam.  Muslims could lament about the loss of Jerusalem more so as could Christians.  Jews could view it as an attack on Israel's power there.  However, to the educated viewer, it does the exact opposite: It inspires.  It shows the tremendous chivalry that existed between good men and shows you how the extremists ruined a lot and brought more death to innocents.Though it is true that most Crusaders were extremists and I doubt that there would have been so many rational ones (as the movie depicts; it is definitely "updated" for the 21st century).  Scott shows you the parallels between a crazy Guy de Lusignan to a bin Laden or even a neo-con.  He portrays the de Lusignan as idiotic.  He also tries to show you how blindly mad many of the Christian Crusaders were.  He does this by having a man quote at the beginning (something along the lines of) "It is not a sin to kill an infidel."  The viewer should make the bin Laden/ terrorist connection very early on.The film's climatic scene (SPOILER alert) where Balian (Bloom) and Saladin meet to discuss terms of surrender, Saladin promises that no one will be hurt and that they will all be allowed safe passage out of Jerusalem.  Balian replies that when Christian crusaders took Jerusalem that they killed Muslims (and Jews) in great numbers, so how can I trust you?  And at a point where I got goose bumps he replied (Something like) "I am not them, I am Saladin Saladin."  Yes my friends for that moment CHIVALRY was ALIVE!  Saladin let most of the city's inhabitants go unharmed and did not take revenge on the Christians (though admittedly he did sell some survivors into slavery and did poison the wells including razing the land to prevent Richard the Lionheart from advancing.)  Nonetheless, the moment of chivalry at the end cemented my positive review of the film; it brought everything together nicely and I would have considered it a travesty had Scott left it out.  Scott is trying very hard to show that we can co-exist in this world.  And because I am such an extreme moderate and as a teacher, one who emphasizes coexistence, the historical inaccuracies were fine for me to deal with.  If you know the history and watch this film, it truly has the chance to inspire us all.Although I would have especially liked to see Scott present more of the languages difficulties here (all English, very little Arabic . . there would have been more complexities between communication between the Crusaders, etc) I am sure he did this to appeal to mass audiences and ease their understanding of it all.I applaud Ridley Scott (again) for being bold and trying to show us all that religious and ideological extremism (in all cultures) must be eliminated and goodwill and chivalry (though conflicts will persist) must be absolute.

reviewText: When Ridley Scott goes to make a film, he always seems to have a clear view in mind. but when studios tell him to tinker with his films, his vision ends up getting diminished. Such as what occurred with "Kingdom of Heaven." Although I enjoyed the 144-minute theatrical version, I also noted that the first half of the film did suffer from under-developed characters and rushed storytelling, but was made up for by top-notch visual effects, some good performances, and superb battle scenes. Still, something was missing from the origianal version.But what was missing has been restored in Scott's superb director's cut. The film has been extended to 194-minutes, mostly adding plot and characterization, that gives the film more of a soul. Now, instead of a good action-epic, we get a film more on the lines of "Gladiator:" a character-driven historical epic, with fine performances by the main stars. I believe that if Scott had been allowed to release this version in the theaters, a great number of the cast and crew would've been up for Oscars.The DVD presents the film in a Roadshow presentation that would've been normal for a film of this kind back in the fifties and sixties, and features fine picture and sound. The special features are also fascinating, giving insight into the making of this epic film, and the reasons why it may have failed here in the states.Overall, this version of "Kingdom of Heaven" is a masterpiece of film that ranks with films like "Gladiator," "Alexander," and "Braveheart" as one of the greatest historical epics of our time.Movie/DVD Grade: A+

reviewText: After such a long time of anticipation, when I got to see the theater release, I walked out disappointed. And all because of one 'little' point,How the hell did a blacksmith learn how to fight and defend a city after nothing more than a ten minute swordfighting lesson from his father?A big fan of knights and crusader myths since I was a boy in the fifties, there were scenes in the film that just sent chills up my spine: the crusaders riding into the village; crusaders going about their business in Messina; the first approach into Jerusalem; the approach of the christian army onto the battlefield with the shining cross and the forest of spears and flags.It was everything I wanted to see in a good crusader movie.But, "How the hell..."The directors cut fixed it.Now, "How the hell could any studio exec have thought that information was superfluous?"The dvd version is now one of the best movies ever, IMHO.Except for:"Overture"Beautiful, perfect intro to the movie. I closed my eyes and waited for the start of the film. Then "BAM!" 20th century fox fanfare and studio logo crap!Not good.The young Prince holds his hand over the candle until his skin chars and doesn't feel anything. When he appears next, there is no bandage or evidence of damage or indication that enough time has passed for the damage to heal. Later, the wax drips on his arm and his mother notices he doesn't feel it. That really could have been enough. I think the candle flame scene was inserted in case we were too stupid to get the candle wax implication.When the wall is breeched at the end of the siege and both armies swarm the opening, the seething mass of fighting men who clog the breech is a perfectly realized moment. A small number of doomed men doing the actual fighting, pressed so close they could hardly wield their weapons (described sometimes as being so closely pressed that the dead could not fall), while the ones in back push forward against each other. I was surprised when the camera pulled up to an overhead shot and saw that both armies were holding back while the breech was contested by smaller contingents. This may have been more to the truth but I really wanted to see it the way the old romatic painters used to portray it: Both armies pushing their way in.[...]The last meeting/duel between Balian and Guy de Lusignan was not satisfying.In the original release, Guy just disappears. I just figured they killed him.Would it have been better if Balian had killed him? No. The director's cut scene is fitting with Balian's character's motivations, but still, the scene did not satisfy.Now the only complaint I have about the movie is one that is really a compliment to the director:Godfrey and his knights: I understand that Ridley enjoys the fact that we are surprised that many of them die so soon. But, even in the original version, I walked out wishing that we could see another movie about them and their adventures. As the camera panned over their dead faces, I wanted to know where they had been and what they had done.I still do.I wish the black muslim had been able to pull his saracen blade during the fight!And the Hospitaler! I want to see another movie with more of him.I've read that Scott would like to do another movie set in this time and I hope like hell he gets to do it.One other little thing:The fight on the beach. There are three horses. But only two go to Jerusalem. I didn't see one get killed. Balian gives his horse to the Muslim but rides one away. What happened to the other horse?
summary: director's cut / mostly good and a little bad

reviewText: The cinematography was fabulously done, costuming, acting WOW and general plot line was riveting.However, snarl snarl... my main gripe with the movie stems not from the overly nice treatment of Islam, which provided only the good half of Islamic experience and some nuances that could easily be lost to the viewer who knows little of Islamic life style and culture.  The concern is with the excessively heavy handed and one sided presentation of European Christianity (Roman Catholicism). The European Church of this period, which was essentially one unified Church, (pre protestants, pre reformers, pre rosaries, pre born-againism), with both negative and positive aspects. The movie misses the reality of the pageantry and religious practices of the Christians. The only prayers shown are the corporate prayers of the Muslims.Christians of the period would have had community based services with Divine Office (up until Vatican II the Latin 7 times a day prayers of the "Orders".... those Templars.. and fervent Believers), pageants, plays, processions through towns with icons, and other religious symbols. The Churches were extremely ornate, the movie ends with one empty room with one bronze cross that Saladin puts back on a table. Bull-cookies! The Churches of Jerusalem would have had a strong influence of the Orthodox (the third group of Believers of the Book slaughtered by the European Christians with the Jews and Muslims in Jerusalem). The Churches and Holy Sites would have been (and still are today) covered with carvings, statues, stonework, Icons of Saints, or Christ. Icons covered in gold gilt, encrusted with precious stones. The intensity of awe inspiring beauty, the bling-bling, of the Church was in strict contrast to the crappy life of the average poor half starved peasantry. The Church's faade represents paradise of Heaven the power of God.  The movie never once even shows a Eucharistic, smells and bells, service the central pillar of the historic Christian faith.  The Dome of the Rock (A Muslim Holy Site) was of equal stature, the majesty or bling-bling of the Islamic architecture also is to show the Glory of God to the masses, which in turn is the hope of Paradise, for Muslims that lived crappy half starved peasant lives.The differences in life and faith practice between the Muslims and Christians would have been a fantastic showing similarities and differences. But no this movie and the corresponding A&E; and History Channel documentaries are definitely against Christianity.One leaves the movie thinking what they are supposed to, the Kingdom of Heaven is a slick propaganda piece that shows everyone why they should hate Christians today and especially those who follow the practices of the Historical Christian Church.One final thought regarding the martyrdom that the movie espouses. A martyr is killed by a person of a different faith, that requires a Muslim to be killed for the sake of being Muslim by a non-Muslim, and conversely a Christian killed by a non-Christian for believing in the Christ, both faiths would have had the same teaching at that time. Martyrdom was like a first class ticket to Paradise / Heaven. My point here, is the priest toward the end who advocates conversion to Islam, was a plant for the propagandistic message of the movie, Christians and in particular the historic - 2000 year old faith and practice - Christians of Europe suck and had no real Faith.I would suspect that the lack of commercial success is due to not so subtle Christian bashing.
summary: Beautiful, Well Done, but very Uneven Treatment of Religions..

reviewText: Kingdom of Heaven is about one man's dedication to be the perfect knight in order to protect the innocent civilians of Jerusalem. He seeks redemption for having murdered his own half-brother and sticks to his principles and refuses to "do a little evil for a greater good". In the end he gives up the city of Jerusalem to save its inhabitants.The primary plot of the movie is and external quest: battles to save Jerusalem. The turning points of the main plot are driven by internal and relationship struggles: the knight trying to do the moral thing and giving up fortune and love in the process.Unfortunately, probably because I watched the extended version of the movie, the main plot doesn't get going until half way through the movie. The back story up to the knight's arrival in Jerusalem (which doesn't include a lot of key turning points) wastes more than an hour of screen time before the main story gets rolling. And the first significant turning point is the knight having an affair with the princess, making his later choices of staying squeaky clean as a moral knight seem hollow and arbitrary. The knight, aside from the justified murder at the beginning of the film, doesn't go through much of an arc: he is good near the beginning and stays good to the end. The redemption arc of the princess is a little more interesting but less relevant since she's not our protagonist. So we end up watching a squeaky clean "good" guy go through heroic actions against clearly "bad" guys and watch the very expense set piece battles. Unfortunately internal and relationship driving forces feel hollow. I might have been distracted enough by the action to not really care, but at 3 hours long (the extended version) its hard to not notice the slack internal and relationship arcs.Some ways that might have made it better: cut the entire first act prior to his arrival in Jerusalem, yes including his dad Liam Neeson so the main story gets going right away. Make the protagonist go through more of an arc: place some of his not so good choices into the middle of the story so we don't watch a "good" guy go through 2.5 hours being a goody two shoes. Make his redemption less about his mourning of his perfect wife since he goes around sleeping with a married princess. Or: just admit that this is a simple Action film so pack all the action into 90 minutes so we have no time to worry about the internal and relationship arcs.My Story Chart of the movie is at storycharts.ca
summary: Unwavering good is the only way to save our souls

reviewText: To me this felt like an attempt to recreate the sucess of Gladiator.  There were many similarities - the scenes of old Jerusalem were very much like those of Rome (albeit equally spectacular!), the battle scenes were filmed in the same style as those in Gladiator, and the lead character's story was similar.  What was missing was the character development.  Orlando Bloom did a reasonably good job with the lead - he doesn't have quite the gravitas he needs to make the big speeches before a battle, but other than that he did a fine job (and I gotta admit, he looks even better than Russell in those period clothes!).  Liam Neeson and Jeremy Irons were both excellent, as usual.  But I never got as emotionally involved with the characters as with Maximus - the story jumps from spectacular scene to spectacular scene without enough tying it all together.  We're clearly supposed to feel some sympathy and respect for Salidin, but that's never justified.  In the end, it leaves you feeling a  bit empty.  Perhaps the 40 minutes that will supposedly be in the "director's cut" will fill in those blanks.  Ridley, you've got the scenery, costumes and special effects down - next time spend a little more money and effort on the script.
summary: Blame the script - not the actors

reviewText: Look, I love the film production values ... I love the period, the locations, the story, the swords and the history but there are a couple of things that bugged me no end.1. - Bloom would not have survived 5 mins outside his Blacksmithing forge in reality ...2. - Blooms character had 5 mins training from his dad in the woods before the townsmen descended upon the camp and with one special move he seemed to defeat all comers and then needed not one bit of training for the rest of the film!3. - Blooms character seemed to go from a forge to being a general who knew tactics and all other manner of the arts of war, seemingly from the ether!As someone who knows swords and actually trains with swords in HEMA, these things are plot holes you could drive a large planet through and still not touch the sides! Loves everything else, but the shark jumping was in some instances so profound that one was left to ponder whether a dinosaur might appear at any moment!Big film, big story ... big plot holes ... but it manages to charm and gets away with it if you can only suspend that disbelief long enough.

reviewText: What a difference 45 minutes of extra footage makes!As a fan of the great historical epics such as "Braveheart" and "Gladiator", I had high hopes for this film when it was released in the theaters.  Like most people, I was disappointed with that version, which felt rushed, incoherent and whose characters lacked depth.Thank goodness we now have Director's Cut DVDs.  This film is so vastly improved by the added material that it is difficult to believe I was watching the same movie.  Balian, Sibylla, and Godfrey particularly benefit from this version as we learn more of their histories and the events that motivate them.Almost miraculously, Orlando Bloom's acting seems improved in this version.  Some of his speeches ("Rise a Knight!") remain cause for a roll of the eyes, but in this version he seemed to be much more acceptable.If Russell Crowe had been cast as Balian and the Director's cut of the film released in theaters, there is no doubt it would have been a Best Picture nominee.
summary: Theatrical Release = 2 stars;  Director's Cut = 4.5 stars

reviewText: It wasn't Gladiator but it wasn't bad.  It was actually very entertaining, which is the director's intention. The climax seige of Jerusalem was very well done; I'll never tire of watching trebuchets in action (especially real ones as opposed to CG ones).  Good movie.

reviewText: This is one of the few intelligent movies out there, and probably one of only three 'intelligent' epics, the others being SPARTACUS and LAWRENCE OF ARABIA.  By intelligent I'm referring to an extremely literate script, shades of gray politics within a world of black and white emotions, in this case the christians vs. muslims and vice versa.  This screenplay is extremely well-grounded in historical fact, like the other two films I mention.  Some people may have problems with this film because it is not as fast-paced as a slasher film, or as gory as GLADIATOR (which sprang from the 1960s FALL OF THE ROMAN EMPIRE film).  Those films are predictable and also violence-ridden.  This film is dealing with the complexities of a situation where the only people who realize they are in a no-win situation, are also intelligent enough to realize they are locked into a black-and-white world they cannot control, as most people function via stark motives, hatreds, and loves.  Saladin, portrayed here so wonderfully, was really the "hero" of the Crusades, being so respected in real life, even Christians in Europe would name their babies for him.  In a sense, the Christians are the bad guys of the time period and also of this film.  Many westerners would be uncomfortable with any story that didn't have their alter-egos exemplifying the ideal.  Saladin was the most intelligent and mature of the rulers seeking to (re)claim Jerusalem as the centerpiece holy place of three religions, and he is treated respectfully and accurately, as is Baldwin of Jerusalem.  but the closer you get to the religious "fanatics", the more you can see the film as a diatribe against fanaticism, though it is against fanaticism of any kind, whether christian or muslim.  For Balian, the hero whose journey the audience is tracing, he starts off as a rather desperate young man in mourning, spiritually confused, and in need of a new foundation: he finds it in his father and in his father's devotion to the king of Jerusalem, and Balian takes this cause as his own.  But overriding all this is Balian's need for personal redemption, and much of the movie is his internal struggle as he has left the village he's known all his life, is now truly cosmopolitan, and has to adapt to everything while remaining true to his moral code, and there is some inconsistencies as there are growing pains - an affair with a future queen, but denial of marriage to her if it means the execution of her husband. All of the cast is well-suited to their roles, including Eva Green (as future queen Sibyla) and especially Orlando Bloom.  They both have the requisite look of the period as well as the talent and especially expressive features to convey the characters' thoughts and emotions.  Often the most riveting moments are when caught in close-up, either character silent in repose - they remind me of the SUNSET BOULEVARD line "We had faces then!"  These two have FACES.  They are also both striking looking in coloring, making them a good physical match on-screen.  The obligatory romance between the Balian and Sibyla characters seems to be the only hollywood movie indulgence the director took.  In conclusion, DVDs are hard to rate, because are you rating the movie or the entire package, which includes the extras?  If possible I would give 5 stars for the film itself and only 2 stars for the package, as the extras comprise only promotional background documentaries shown on the TV and internet, and the theatrical preview.  They are informative, but there are none of the television ads, nor any deleted scenes or commentary track, which seems amazing.  So, LORD OF THE RINGS still holds the crown for the most complete set of extras ever assembled (a truly exhaustive amount).
